tweets.text:
Horses are wonderful animals. Majestic and trustworthy animals. 

Contrast this with Walleys Quarry Landfill run by @RedIndustries2 who simply don‚Äôt care.  

They poison a town and don‚Äôt care if it‚Äôs people or horses.  

Come on @EnvAgencyMids get the whip and sort it. https://t.co/JqHHm7JFqa

tweets.text:
Out of the loop, does anyone know why this move?
"From Monday 31 May HM Land Registry will no longer offer Flood Risk Indicator reports through our Find a property service."
@amy_shann @StinkStopthe @EnvAgencyMids Exactly. Many many landfills across the country run without a fuss or breaches that don‚Äôt have any issues. No NO excuses!!!!!
@EnvAgencyMids Operations need to be STOPPED until this is a well run compliant site WITHOUT any breaches !!! #StopTheStink @StinkStopthe
@Feargal_Sharkey @EnvAgency @JournoChar @ITVCentral Allowing the water to be poisoned, allowing the air to be poisoned. What are we paying these people for? #stopthestink.
@JournoChar @ITVCentral Abject failure of @EnvAgency agency and @DefraGovUK , but the fault ultimately lies with governments, especially from 2010 onwards.

On the @EnvAgency call on Wed a gentleman gave a heartbreaking account of how his elderly mother can‚Äôt breathe when the gas comes strongly into her house and has been to hospital ten times now due to gas exposure.This is far beyond not good enough @RedIndustries2 @BGFinvestments

Our latest #WalleysQuarry update is now live. Read it here ‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/ylefAJ5mn0

We are challenging the operator every step of the way to take action to reduce the odour levels from their operations & the impact these are having on the local community

#NewcastleUnderLyme https://t.co/2GBqg2AQHY

A tunnel through fractured chalk, which will most likely take out the River Misbourne. But @HS2ltd nor the @EnvAgency have taken note of the experts. 

It needs to be at least 7m deeper. https://t.co/c4D0NfcGLt

EXPOSED: Soaring levels of damaging phosphates in our rivers are revealed in a special @ITVCentral  investigation tonight.

One river in the Midlands was almost 50 times the safe limit.

And we hear evidence of the deadly affect it's having on wildlife.

https://t.co/8A2A1gE2au https://t.co/HkXJpFpqKe

urls.title: Dying fish and 'gunge-filled' rivers as pollution soars to dangerous levels | ITV News
urls.description: Our exclusive investigation has found the River Soar near Loughborough had phosphate levels 50 times higher than safe limits.

tweets.text:
@EnvAgencyMids @Cap_it_off @DrMariaNeira @antheaturner @JuliaBradbury @mwilliamsthomas 

The annoyance level for hydrogen sulphide (h2s) is 7 ugm3. 

Would anyone at the EA like to comment on why we are seeing figures as high as 1017 ugm3. 

#StopTheStink https://t.co/G4jobNaxsi

tweets.text: @Bigdwazda @RedIndustries2 @EnvAgencyMids They are most definitely majestic animals. To see them like that is heartbreaking, they must suffer too. Along with all the other pets in the townüíî #stopthestink

@Bigdwazda @EnvAgencyMids @Cap_it_off @DrMariaNeira @AntheaTurner @JuliaBradbury @mwilliamsthomas They might also want to comment on why the site is currently operational while this is happening. We didn't get an adequate explanation this week on the Q&A.

To be clear, the only reason it isn't  breaking the WHO health level constantly is the strong day/night cycle. It spends most of the day hovering around annoyance levels then shoots well into the hundreds(!) night after night #stopthestink @StinkStopthe @AaronBell4NUL @EnvAgency https://t.co/3ZHXbPvGMW

tweets.text: @EnvAgencyMids you currently assess H2S from against annoyance (30 min avg 7ug/m3) and health (24hr avg 150ug/m3), what are the effects of several hundred ug/m3 for 12 hours day after day? This is our nightly reality. @StinkStopthe #stopthestink @PHE_uk @AaronBell4NUL
More appalling works at Cley from the Environmental Destruction Agency... https://t.co/veZch7FVw6

tweets.text: @Bigdwazda @EnvAgencyMids @Cap_it_off @DrMariaNeira @AntheaTurner @JuliaBradbury @mwilliamsthomas Hi Darren, could you follow me back so I can DM you about this? Thanks!

Met with @EnvAgencyYNE today to discuss natural flood management works at Broughton nr Skipton. Modelling for the Upper Aire catchment shows conclusively that here, of all the NFM interventions, tree planting and soil aeration will have the greatest effect on reducing flood risk https://t.co/27oUTnFDYL

Are you at risk of #flooding?

If you're not sure, visit our page signposting @EnvAgencyNW flood risk maps and flood warning service. It also explains types of #floodrisk, who's responsible for managing it, and more! üëâ https://t.co/xYGKCzN6AI https://t.co/ejSEkJGSh2

@markeltro @EnvAgencyMids @Cap_it_off @DrMariaNeira @AntheaTurner @JuliaBradbury @mwilliamsthomas I agree, the site should be suspended and they should be made to concentrate on stopping the pollution.

All on @AlokSharma_RDG watch -@COP26 is more of a priority to those who window dress only. 
At home chinless wonder @JamesBevanEA CEO hides from the press as the @EnvAgency are defenceless. https://t.co/8rp1DnglF7

tweets.text: The new roadmap sets out how @envagency will reduce emissions by 45% to hit the 2030 #netzero target. https://t.co/OZBZ3wSFHs @greenbizjournal

urls.title: Low-carbon concrete flood defences to help Environment Agency hit net zero by 2030 ‚Ä¢ Green Business Journal
urls.description: New roadmap sets out how EA will reduce emissions by 45% to hit 2030 net zero target. The Environment Agency (EA) has pledged to default to low-carbon concrete when constructing flood defences and other critical infrastructure projects, provided they meet performance requirements, as it sets out its roadmap to hit net zero as an organisation [‚Ä¶]
